Journal.Title: Water science and technology : a journal of the International Association on Water Pollution Research

Article.ArticleTitle: Treatability of biodiesel wastewaters by using KMnO<sub>4</sub> and KMnO<sub>4</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> processes and kinetic analysis.

AbstractText: This study aims to investigate the treatability of electrocoagulated biodiesel wastewater (ECBD) by KMnO<sub>4</sub> and KMnO<sub>4</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> processes. The ECBD removal efficiencies of both KMnO<sub>4</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> and KMnO<sub>4</sub> methods were compared, and the COD and MeOH removal efficiencies with the KMnO<sub>4</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> process gave better results than the KMnO<sub>4</sub> process. For the ECBD removal efficiencies, the experimental parameters including pH, KMnO<sub>4</sub> dose, O<sub>3</sub> dose and reaction time were optimized by changing one parameter at a time. As a result of 6 h of KMnO<sub>4</sub> oxidation, 91.74% of COD and 95.93% of MeOH removal was achieved under the optimum conditions. However, the COD and MeOH removal efficiencies have been obtained under optimum conditions for KMnO<sub>4</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> as 97.79% and 98.30%, respectively. The second-order kinetic model has been found to be the most suitable model for both processes and the R<sup>2</sup> has been found as 0.999 and 0.999 for KMnO<sub>4</sub> and KMnO<sub>4</sub>/O<sub>3</sub>, respectively. The reaction k has also been calculated as 6 × 10<sup>-5</sup> L·mg<sup>-1</sup>·min<sup>-1</sup> and 1.63 × 10<sup>-4</sup> L·mg<sup>-1</sup>·min<sup>-1</sup> for COD and MeOH in KMnO<sub>4</sub> oxidation, respectively. Furthermore, the k has also been calculated as 6 × 10<sup>-5</sup> L·mg<sup>-1</sup>·min<sup>-1</sup> and 1.6 × 10<sup>-4</sup> L·mg<sup>-1</sup>·min<sup>-1</sup> for COD and MeOH in KMnO<sub>4</sub>/O<sub>3</sub> oxidation, respectively.
